title: What book will win the 2019 National Book Award for fiction?
possible_answers: Sabrina & Corina: Stories by Kali Fajardo-Anstine
Black Leopard, Red Wolf by Marlon James
The Other Americans by Laila Lalami
preds: Using GoodReads as a proxy for subjective quality (popularity), it's 3.1 (5,163), 4.33 (1,329), 3.49 (9,235), 3.96 (4,043) and 3.87 (6,167). In the case of fiction, I think there is a bias toward promoting good, lesser known work. So, B stands out. I'm taking 10% from A and putting it on B and then taking 5% from C and splitting it over D/E.

Crowd doesn't seem to have any strong leanings. I tried to think about using historical data, but from looking at the National Book Awards website, the judges seem to change every year, which makes it a little harder to believe that past information is predictive of future outcomes. [1] In addition, some have written about how the awards are not a reward for success, which makes it hard to believe that using sales data or book review information is predictive of award outcomes. [2] I looked at a list of winners, and though I think I'm pretty well read, but I don't really recognize many of the more recent winners (post 2000). [3] This is suggestive that this is really not a popularity contest.  Of course, I haven't really investigated data on these issues, (whether sales, for example, is predictive of outcomes), but I doubt I would find anything, and if I did I don't how believable it would be. Given that the crowd doesn't seem to have any strong leaning (or any explanations), I'm just gonna predict even across the slate. I'm hopeful someone will think of a good tactic to predict this question.   [1] https://www.nationalbook.org/national-book-awards/how-works/
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Book_Award#Current_process
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_winners_of_the_National_Book_Award#Fiction
